sn37.3:1.1: Here the Buddha expresses empathy for the lot of women in the culture of his times.
sn37.3:1.3: An unmarried girl (kumāribhūta) under twenty was said to be not mature enough for full ordination (Bi Pc 71:1.11), which is the same age as for the monks. A gihigatā of just twelve, however, might be ordained. Gihigatā is explained as “gone to the place of a man” (purisantaragatā, Bi Pc 66:2.7); i.e. a girl who is married. This item precedes menstruation, which also suggests the age of twelve. The Hindu tradition says a girl should be given in marriage before puberty (Manu 9.89; Gautama 18.21; Vaśiṣṭha 17.70; Baudhāyana 4.1.11). If no suitable husband is found, three years after puberty she is free to choose her own (Manu 9.90; Gautama 18.20; Baudhāyana 4.10.14). Yama (Vīramitrodaya Saṁskāra, p. 773) says she may choose a husband after the age of twelve.
sn37.3:1.5: Utu is “season”; it includes the fortnight that begins with menstruation (see note on MN 38:26.2).
sn37.3:1.11: The mutual obligations of husbands and wives are mentioned from a Buddhist perspective at DN 31:30.1, where the wife is not said to “serve” the husband, but to be kind to him. A wife’s “service” (pāricariya) was domestic and also sexual (Bu Ss 4:1.2.7). No Buddhist text, however, justifies the use of violence in marriage (as at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.4.7). Manu 9.3 says a woman must always be subject to a man, whether father, husband, or son. Manu 9.11 lists a wife’s duties such as managing household finances, cleaning, cooking, and housekeeping, as well as minor religious observances.
